Yesterday it was triggered by an e-mail (well, actually something I read). After telling him that I am capable of falling in love and want to do so very badly, "Jay" said to me: you may say this now (about love), but almost everything you tell me, and your actions show a person who protects herself at every turnâ¦rarely shows her true feelings (your writing vs. what comes out of your mouth)... is more insecure than romantic (needs a couple glasses of wine to begin showing affection) and has been so for so long, that she doesn't even want to announce "I want a husband I'm madly in love with". instead, you take the stance, "i want a 'partner' (a business arrangement)and I recognize there will be downtimes in which i may cheat" ok, so maybe not those exact words, but you know what i mean. finally, rest assured my impression of you is of someone who wants love, but has no interest in risking it all for love. i.e. won't be open enough to let it happen. Heâs right. Heâs not the first person to notice and point-out to me that I need âa couple of glasses of wine to begin showing affection.â"Peter" called me out on this as well. However,"Jay" is the first to capture my reasons for acting how I do. Also, he is the first to help me reach that level in my subconscious that allows me to see me â the real me. The one who knows what I want. The one who has always known. On our first date he told me that I desperately wanted to have kids. My initial reaction was that of pure shock. I thought to myself, â(gasp!) How chauvinistic of him to think that I want what just about every other twenty-something year old woman wants.â Only after spending more time with him, growing to like him very much and seeing him as an incredible candidate for a husband and father, did I realize he was absolutely right. Do you know why I am afraid to use the term âhusband?â Itâs because, to some men there is a certain sense of âbaggageâ attached to this concept. I choose to use the term âlife partnerâ because itâs a general term, under which âhusbandâ falls. I have noticed that many couples â the men, especially have problems making the transition from âboyfriendâ to âhusbandâ regardless of how long they have been with their significant other, and even if they have already been living like a married couple. There is something implied in this term that can make men flip-out and become scared that they are trapped with no way out. Because I am sensitive to this idea, and I still want a life partner, or husband, I opt not to scare away a man that I want to be with by potentially putting a negative idea in his head. Iâve seen couples that have been together for what seems like an eternity â living together and having children. But, the minute they decide to make the relationship official (i.e get married) they donât work â as couple. Itâs purely psychological. I know this. I am prepared to deal with the psychology behind the idea of marriage. However, I canât convince a man of this. And, I donât want to lose the man I love and want to be with because he canât handle a label. Being a woman, I can adapt. Women can become ready, while men need to already be there. I have made an agreement with myself that I would go along with whatever would make the relationship work â as long as I still get what I want out of it: a life partner to love and who will love me the same in return. If the man I love wants to get married, I will marry him. I will want to marry him equally as much. But, if the man I love is afraid of being labeled a âhusband,â but knows he wants to be with me, I will be with him, live with him and be committed to him as if we were in a marriage. I donât need a legal document to prove my love and commitment to a man. I donât need to change my name to prove this either. I just need the love and commitment â everything else is purely icing on the cake. This being said, the only reason I would strongly encourage marriage is if kids fall into the equation. In my opinion, to raise happy children you need to bring them up in a healthy home environment. A healthy home consists of a situation where there is a mother figure and a father figure in a loving, committed relationship. Every child needs representation from both parents during his/her development, especially in their early years. Whether the child is a boy or a girl, having a mom and a dad is extremely instrumental in shaping their perceptions and future relationships when they become adults. The marriage part comes into play to provide the children with the concept of creating a family and a home in a traditional manner. It instills values of tradition and reinforces the ideas behind commitment. In a way, I see it somewhat as a promise that the parents make to their children that says to them that they are bound together and always will be.
